Naltrexone is also used as a weight management medication when combined with bupropion AKA Wellbutrin, a common antidepressant. Both are used for the same reasons as for non-drug addictions and overeating can be treated as an addiction. I actually take two medications that have been repurposed. Amitriptyline which is a tricyclic antidepressant is used in my case to treat migraines. And an antimalarial medication known as hydroxychloroquine or plaquenil is being used in my case to treat antiphospholipid syndrome (which is a disease that causes excessive blood clotting within the patients circulatory system.) Repurposing of medications in this manner is a growing trend. There are multiple reasons for this. For one a drug that is already FDA approved need not be retested for safety only for efficacy. There is no need to design new manufacturing techniques or equipment. And brand recognition can go a long way to the public's acceptance of the newly repurposed medication. Take for instance how quickly aspirin was accepted as a means to helping to lower the risk of heart attack. Also commonly used medications have strong track records of not manifesting rare but deadly side effects that only show up once the drug is in wide distribution.

I my case the addition of Plaquenil to my daily regimen has both lowered the occurrence rate of blood clots but has also served as a substance that has greatly reduced my migraine frequency and severity. This was also true when I switched from coumadin to a heparin based anticoagulant called Lovenox that we later switched to another variant that is administered in pill form called Xarelto. Together these three medications have drastically improved my quality of life.

Now seems like a good time to bring up anticholinergic agents. Anticholinergic agents inhibit acetylcholine in the brain, a neurotransmitter that effects involuntary muscle movements. Common anticholinergic agents like atropine and scopolamine can be found in members of the nightshade family like devil's bells and Angel's bells.
These plants have incredibly potent and terrifying psychoactive as well as physical effects.
Scopolamine can also be used for mind control (see devil's breath) but in low doses causes intense hallucinations.
It should be noted that countless medications are derived from these anticholinergic agents.
Poisonous anticholinergic flowers can also be used as narcotics but they're deliriants as apposed to typical hallucinogens, meaning that telling reality from drug induced delirium is incredibly difficult for people on Belladonna (nightshade) or datura (devil's bells, jimson weed, devil's weed)
I don't find it unlikely that some of the medicines listed may be derivatives of anticholinergic agents.

Glucagon - used for low blood sugar, also treats beta blocker and calcium channel overdose

Gabapentin - for seizures also used for pain

Several antidepressants also used for pain

Botox - also used for neurological disorders

Metformin - in addition to diabetes also used to treat PCOS and fertility issues

Metoclopramide - acid reflux also used to treat insufficient milk production

Quinidine - antimalarial also used as an anti arrhythmia med

Erythromycin and azithromycin - antibiotic also used for gut motility

Naloxone - Narcan used for opioid rescue when taken orally can be used for narcotic induced constipation

Intralipids - for IV nutrition also used for anesthesia rescue

Bupropion - antidepressant for smoking cessation

Statins - anticholesterol medication like Lipitor used as an anti inflammatory, immunomodulator and possible antibiotic.

Another drug with a surprising secondary use is acetaminophen--also known as paracetamol or Tylenol. While it's often used over-the-counter to treat physical pain (which it does, at least in part, by reducing signaling in pain-detecting parts of the brain), it can also be used to treat the pain caused by social rejection. It turns out that the brain uses very similar parts of the brain to detect both physical and social/emotional pain, and acetaminophen can act on both (DeWall et al., 2010).

To my knowledge, studies are still in their preliminary phases, but taking a regular dose of Tylenol seems to help calm negative emotional reactions in people with certain personality and mood disorders (like borderline personality disorder; Roberts et al., 2017), and it's been suggested that it might help people recover from complicated grief (Vance & Bui, 2018). It's not quite to the level of being an accepted pharmacological treatment for these conditions, and taking a high dose of Tylenol too often carries its own risks (hello, liver damage), but maybe someday it will be used to supplement other medications or to treat milder conditions on its own.

In the meantime, maybe try talking to friends or listening to cathartic music to get over that breakup :D
